review: I own both an Apple TV and a Roku 3.  I originally bought the Apple TV but quickly found myself wanting more channels.  As a primarily Apple user, I didn't want to replace the Apple TV because I love the airplay mirroring and streaming from my Mac or iOS devices.  The Apple TV is very fast and responsive, especially compared to the online apps in my Internet capable TV.  So far, I have not encountered any buffering or sync issues with the apple TV.  I originally had it connected with an ethernet cable but after purchasing the Roku, I now run it wireless in the family room.  I keep the Apple TV in the family room so other family members can mirror or stream from their iOS devices.As I mentioned, my only complaint with Apple TV is a lack of channels. The only premium channel available is HBO Go.  However, the only extra premium offered on Roku is Epix.  Also, some of the extra channels are pretty worthless, like SyFy.  Forget full episodes of current and former SyFy faves like Being Human, Helix or Battlestar Galactica.  The SyFy channel on Roku offers nothing more than snippets.  Dozens and dozens of minutes long snippets.  Uh, no thanks.  Apple TV does offer several news, weather, specialty and children's channels (like Disney).  There is no Amazon instant video as offered on Roku.  Movies and television shows that aren't available on any other channels must be purchased through iTunes.  The included remote is small and limited to basic playback functions or text entry using the directional arrows.  A remote app is available for free from iTunes that gives you more flexibility and is much more efficient for certain tasks, especially text entry.  The keyboard in the iOS remote app will make you never again want to use the directional arrows on the bundled remote.  All remotes work through the network, not bluetooth or infrared.  I can actually control the Apple TV in the family room from any other room.  Last week, I was able to display photos from my iPhone two rooms away.  In addition to the iPhone, the app works on iPods and iPads as well.So far, I've had my Apple TV since the end of November.  As of mid-January I have not experienced any major issues with A/V sync or buffering.  It worked flawlessly when I originally had it connected via an ethernet cable.  Once I switched to wifi, I still never encountered any sync issues, however, I'll occasionally get a very quick buffering.  It is infrequent and  doesn't last more than a second or two.  I actually get more buffering delays when watching streaming video wirelessly on much more powerful laptops.If you're trying to decide between Apple TV and Roku, I suggest Roku if you're really into watching online content and want the greatest variety of channels available.  Apple TV currently can't come close to the number of channels offered by Roku.  If you own a Mac or iOS devices and get your content primarily from iTunes or plan to do a lot of streaming /mirroring from your Apple device, Apple TV is a no-brainer.  I actually fall into both categories, so I own both.  With recent sale prices, they were still pretty affordable.
